A study of selected topics in virology, parasitology, mycology and infrequently encountered bacteriology pathogens. Assignments will include pathogenicity, identification protocol, lab problems and disease correlation. (2-0) Prerequisite: Admittance into MLS program.
courses.prerequisites: Admission to Medical Laboratory Science prorgam (Previous, Required)

courses.title: Clinical Chemistry II
courses.description: Continuation of the two semester Clinical Chemistry sequence. Discussions and assignments regarding method comparisons, therapeutic drugs, hormones and selected laboratory problems associated with diagnostic and advanced testing techniques. (2-0) Prerequisite: Admittance into MLS program.
courses.prerequisites: Admission to Medical Laboratory Science program (Previous, Required)

courses.title: Principles of Laboratory Ops
courses.description: Introductory course in the principles and techniques of quality assurance and improvement as applied in all phases of laboratory services including the pre-analytical and post analytical components. Students investigate professional roles, responsibilities, problem solving and conflict resolution techniques as related to leadership and laboratory administration as well as human resource, education, information and financial management issues and planning. (2-0) Prerequisite: Admittance into MLS program.
courses.prerequisites: Admission to Medical Laboratory Science program (Previous, Required)

courses.title: Clinical Laboratory I
courses.description: Laboratory exercises and methods will be performed in clinical hematology, clinical chemistry, and molecular lab diagnostics to supplement lecture content, reinforce procedures, and simulate clinical laboratory workload.
courses.prerequisites: Admission to the Medical Laboratory (B.S.) Program, and MLS MLS 420, MLS 450 (Concurrent, Required)

courses.title: Clinical Laboratory II
courses.description: Laboratory exercises and methods will be performed in clinical microbiology, immunohematology, and immunology to supplement lecture content, reinforce procedures, and simulate clinical laboratory workload.
courses.prerequisites: MLS 330, MLS 340 (Previous, Required) MLS 410, MLS 430, MLS 440 (Concurrent, Required)

courses.title: Minor Rotations Fieldwork
courses.description: A study of specific topics within the minor departments of the clinical laboratory to include clinical immunology and urinalysis, as well as the preanalytical processes of specimen collection, transport, processing, and reference lab preparation or the application of these topics to other areas within the social, natural or health sciences.
courses.prerequisites: MLS 410, MLS 420, MLS 430, MLS 440, MLS 450, MLS 460,  MLS 460L. (Previous, Required)

courses.title: Clinical Hematology Fieldwork
courses.description: A study of specific topics within the clinical hematology discipline of clinical laboratory science to include hemostasis or the application of clinical hematology and hemostasis to other areas within the social, natural or health sciences.
courses.prerequisites: MLS 410, MLS 420, MLS 430, MLS 440, MLS 450, MLS 460, MLS 460L. (Previous, Required)

courses.title: Clinical Immunohemat Fieldwrk
courses.description: A study of specific topics within the clinical immunohematology discipline of clinical laboratory science or the application of clinical immunohematology to other areas within the social, natural or health sciences.
courses.prerequisites: MLS 410, MLS 420, MLS 430, MLS 440, MLS 450, MLS 460, MLS 460L. (Previous, Required)

courses.title: Clinical Micro Fieldwork
courses.description: A study of specific topics within the clinical microbiology discipline of clinical laboratory science, or the application of clinical microbiology to other areas within the social, natural or health sciences.
courses.prerequisites: MLS 410, MLS 420, MLS 430, MLS 440, MLS 450, MLS 460, MLS 460L. (Previous, Required)

courses.title: Clinical Chemistry Fieldwork
courses.description: A study of specific topics within the clinical chemistry discipline of clinical laboratory science or the application of clinical chemistry to other areas within the social, natural or health sciences.
courses.prerequisites: MLS 410, MLS 420, MLS 430, MLS 440, MLS 450, MLS 460, MLS 460L. (Previous, Required)

courses.title: Clinical Hematology
courses.description: First part of a two semester Clinical Hematology sequence. A comprehensive study of the formation of blood cells, clinical hemostasis, functions of the hematopoietics related to Hematologic disease states and the instrumentation and manual procedures to quantify and identify cells. This will include the morphologic interpretation of blood and bone marrow cells and the analysis of the maturation cell sequence in peripheral blood. Flow cytometry will also be discussed. (2-3) Prerequisites: Admittance into MLS program
courses.prerequisites: Admission to Medical Laboratory Science program (Previous, Required)

courses.title: Clinical Immunohematology I
courses.description: First part of a two semester Clinical Immunohematology sequence. An in depth study emphasizing the basic principles of immunology, human blood group systems, blood group genetics and the theory and application of blood banking techniques. Essential concepts of antibody screening and identification, blood components compatibility testing, donor selection, disease therapy, hemolytic disease of the newborn and blood bank regulations and procedures are stressed. (2-3) Prerequisite: Admittance into MLS program.
courses.prerequisites: Admission to Medical Laboratory Science program (Previous, Required)

courses.title: Clinical Microbiology I
courses.description: First part of a two semester Clinical Microbiology sequence. A comprehensive study of clinically important microorganisms (bacteria, fungi, viruses and parasites) and their role in human disease. Includes the epidemiology and effect on the human host: utilization of biochemical, morphological and serologic characteristics for the isolation and identification of these organisms; includes some life cycles, mode of transmission, identification techniques and the clinical effect of the human host along with an overview of the treatment. Various culture techniques emphasized include microscopy, cultivation, identification antimicrobial susceptibility testing and quality control methods. (2-3) Prerequisites: Admittance into MLS program
courses.prerequisites: Admission to Medical Laboratory Science program (Previous, Required)

courses.title: Clinical Chemistry I
courses.description: First part of a two semester Clinical Chemistry sequence. A comprehensive study of the methods used to determine the chemical composition of body fluids and how those changes relate to pathologic conditions. Operational maintenance and problem solving procedures on a wide range of instruments found in clinical chemistry laboratory, including advanced techniques. Includes testing procedures for a variety of analytes such as; carbohydrates, proteins/enzymes, electrolytes, lipids, bilirubin, creatinine and others and stresses data correlation, interpretation, and quality control procedures. (3-3) Prerequisite: Admittance into MLS program.
courses.prerequisites: Admission to Medical Laboratory Science program (Previous, Required)

courses.title: Molecular Lab Diagnostics
courses.description: An introduction to the fundamentals of nucleic acid biochemistry with an emphasis on molecular laboratory techniques and concepts used in disease diagnosis.
courses.prerequisites: Admitted to the Medical Laboratory Science (B.S.) Program (Previous, Required)

courses.title: Intro to Public Admin
courses.description: This survey course provides a history of public sector and non-profit administration including the works of the major contributors to the discipline. The history of non-profit agencies is also covered with a focus on issues including fund raising, program development and interactions with the public/governmental sector.

courses.title: Conflict Mgt in the Organi
courses.description: An examination of the management of conflict with a focus on public sector and non-profit organizations including mediation, arbitration, administrative hearings and negotiated rule-making. Also covered is the design and implementation of conflict management systems in the context of the organizational development approach.

courses.title: Student Affairs Admin
courses.description: The complex roles and philosophies of higher education in society are explored. The course includes an historical examination of the various types of postsecondary institutions in the context of social and political movements, developments in higher education law and the influence of these factors on student affairs administration.

courses.title: Communication for Admin
courses.description: This course covers communication dynamics in organizational and professional contexts. Also covered are the roles and methods of computer/web-based technological processes in organizational communication.

courses.title: Student Affairs Seminar
courses.description: The course provides a forum for inquiry, discussion, and analysis of issues within university and college student affairs. Students will research curriculum studies, methodologies, and paradigms in the areas to which they aspire.

courses.title: Music Theory I
courses.description: An introduction to the basic materials of music; notation, rhythm, scales, key signatures, intervals, transposition and triads. Elementary part writing and improvisation will begin. Prerequisite: Musicianship assessment and acceptance as music or music education major or music minor. Co-requisite: MUS 111A Aural Skills I
courses.prerequisites: Musicianship assessment and acceptance as music or music MUS 111A (Concurrent, Required)

courses.title: Aural Skills I
courses.description: An introduction to the basics of aural skills including sight singing, melodic, rhythmic, and harmonic dictation, and improvisation. Prerequisite: Musicianship assessment and acceptance as music or music education major or minor. Co-requisite: MUS 111
courses.prerequisites: Musicianship assessment and acceptance as music or music MUS 111 (Concurrent, Required)

courses.title: Musical Exp: Classical Music
courses.description: A study of western classical music from the 18th century to the present.

courses.title: Musical Exp: Non-Western Music
courses.description: A survey of non-Western music covering the music of Asia, Africa and other non-Western cultures. [CI] Communication Intensive

courses.title: Music Exp: Music in the U S
courses.description: A study of American music from the Colonial period to the present, including art, folk and popular styles.

courses.title: Musical Experience: the Piano
courses.description: An introduction to the rudiments of playing the piano and keyboard theory. Students also will study the piano from its origins to the present, including important composers, performers and piano compositions. This course is designed for those with little or no piano experience.

courses.title: Musical Exp: History of Rock
courses.description: A survey of the development of American rock music from a historical and social perspective, with an inclusion of current trends in rock and an emphasis on key innovators of the genre.

courses.title: Intro Music Studies
courses.description: Introduction to skills and materials necessary for college level study of music. Basic study of genres, styles and performing ensembles central to classical music, and techniques of listening, analysis and criticism. Required in their first fall semester of all music and music education majors and minors. Others may enroll with instructor?s permission. Transfer students may apply to the department for exemption.
courses.prerequisites: Music or music education major or minor or instructor  permission. (Previous, Required)

courses.title: Concert Choir
courses.description: A large vocal ensemble that sings a variety of literature that is both accompanied and unaccompanied.
courses.prerequisites: High school choir experience or instructor permission. (Previous, Required)

courses.title: Cardinal Marching Band
courses.description: The Cardinal Marching Band performs at all home football games, at a season ending concert, and at other campus events during the fall semester. The band prepares 3 to 5 halftime shows each season drawing music from the pop, rock, Latin and jazz repertoires. The marching band is open to all students at the university who have had high school marching band experience. First time members require permission of the instructor.
courses.prerequisites: High school marching band experience or instructor  permission. (Previous, Required)

courses.title: Jazz Ensemble
courses.description: Study and performance of classic and contemporary big band literature. Rehearsal twice a week with one performance at end of semester. Emphasis on correct style & improvisation. Open to all students by audition only.

courses.title: Wind Ensemble
courses.description: An instrumental ensemble that plays a broad range of wind literature designed for a single player per part.

courses.title: Cardinal Singers
courses.description: A select chamber vocal ensemble that sings a variety of literature that is both accompanied and unaccompanied. Open to all students by audition only. NOTE: This is a one year committment (Fall & Winter)

courses.title: Arts for Elem Teachers: Music
courses.description: This course explores strategies for integrating musical activities into elementary classrooms, K-8. It offers practical experiences in the creation and teaching of musical activities and provides students with an educationally oriented philosophy for utilization of musical activities in instructional settings.
courses.prerequisites: Admitted elementary education majors only. (Previous, Required)

courses.title: Music Theory III
courses.description: Study of chromatic harmony and modulatory procedures of the Baroque and Classical periods, and of extended chromaticism of the Romantic period, Students will compose style studies as well as analyze excerpts from musical literature. Prerequisite: MUS 211 and MUS 211A or permission of instructor. Co-requisite: MUS 311A
courses.prerequisites: MUS 211, MUS 211A or instructor permission.  (Previous, Required) MUS 311A (Concurrent, Required)

courses.title: Aural Skills III
courses.description: A continuation of aural skills study including identification and dictation of melodic and harmonic progressions, sight singing, and improvisation. Prerequisites: MUS 211 and MUS 211A or permission of the instructor Co-requisite: MUS 311
courses.prerequisites: MUS 211, MUS 211A or instructor permission.  (Previous, Required) MUS 311 (Concurrent, Required)

courses.title: Music History II
courses.description: A study of the history and literature of art music from the late Baroque, Classical and Romantic periods. The course will emphasize the development of various musical genres, relationships between music and society and a study of composers' individual styles through analysis. In addition, the segment on the late Baroque period will include theoretical exercises in contrapuntal techniques.

courses.title: Conducting I
courses.description: A study of the basic techniques of conducting. Students will be given a variety of assignments addressing the topics covered and will conduct the class on a regular basis. Students will be required to attend a rehearsal of an area school, community or professional ensemble and turn in a report based on their observations.

courses.title: Jazz Combo I
courses.description: A departmental course in a subject area not currently listed in the catalog. A descriptive title will appear on the Course Schedule and the transcript.

courses.title: Voice Class
courses.description: An introduction to vocal technique, pedagogy and performance. Students will learn basic vocal anatomy, vocal literature, and singing technique suitable for teaching in the school or studio. Students will also gain experience in solo vocal performance.
courses.prerequisites: Music major or instructor permission. (Previous, Required)

courses.title: Mus Exp: Lis for the Elements
courses.description: This course is intended to help develop the music listening skills of students by focusing on the elements of music as they are used in the music of a variety of cultures, styles and eras.

courses.title: The Musical Exp: Jazz History
courses.description: A survey of the evolution of jazz. Styles such as swing, bebop, cool, avant-garde, fusion, and other recent trends will be studied, both for their musical characteristics and their social and cultural contexts.

courses.title: Concert Band
courses.description: The Concert Band reads, rehearses, and performs a wide variety of music. This includes marches, show tunes, popular music, and contemporary and standard works from the band and wind ensemble repertoire. Student soloists also perform with the band. The concert band performs an annual spring concert and at the Spring Commencement. The Concert Band is open to all students at the university who have been members of their high school bands. First time members require permission of the instructor.
courses.prerequisites: High school band experience or instructor permission.    (Previous, Required)

courses.title: Music Theory II
courses.description: Study of common practice harmony of the 17th and 18th centuries, four-part writing, cadences, nonharmonic tones, harmonic progressions and seventh chords. Prerequisite: MUS 111 and MUS 111A or permission of instructor. Co-requisite: MUS 211A
courses.prerequisites: MUS 111, MUS 111A or instructor permission (Previous, Required) MUS 211A (Concurrent, Required)

courses.title: Aural Skills II
courses.description: A continuation of aural skills study including sight singing, melodic, rhythmic, and harmonic dictation, and improvisation. Prerequisites: MUS 111 and MUS 111A or permission of the instructor. Co-requisite: MUS 211
courses.prerequisites: MUS 111, MUS 111A or instructor permission.  (Previous, Required) MUS 211 (Concurrent, Required)

courses.title: Rhythm Skills
courses.description: This course develops students' skills in playing, identifying, and writing rhythms to a level appropriate for college music majors.
courses.prerequisites: MUS 111, MUS 111A (Previous, Required) MUS 211, MUS 211A (Concurrent, Required)

courses.title: Musical Analysis
courses.description: Students will study a selection of musical compositions that share some fundamental similarities, yet require different approaches to analysis. Examples would be symphonic works, operas or chamber works. The course is designed both to teach methods of musical analysis and to give students an in-depth understanding of a particular body of musical literature. Prerequisite: MUS 311.

courses.title: Advanced Piano Skills
courses.description: An emphasis on keyboard skills rather than developing solo piano technique. The course will focus on harmonizing melodies, playing from chord, nomenclature, improvisation, simple score reading and other practical piano skills.
courses.prerequisites: MUS 311, MUS 311A, and department piano proficiency exam. (Previous, Required)

courses.title: Music Since 1900
courses.description: The course will treat music composed since 1900 from both theoretical and historical standpoints. Students will learn the basis of each theoretical system (such as serialism, neoclassicism and minimalism), compose their own exercises in that system, and study the musical literature written in that system from both analytical and historical perspectives.

courses.title: Instrumental Conducting
courses.description: Continuation of MUS 334 with a focus on instrumental conducting. Students will study more complex conducting techniques and complete in class conducting assignments on a regular basis. The topics of score analysis and rehearsal planning and techniques will also be covered. Students will complete a detailed score analysis and a rehearsal plan for the same score as a final project.

courses.title: Strings Methods
courses.description: An introduction to the theory and practice of playing orchestral string instruments. Students will learn to play all bowed stringed instruments, and will learn the skills necessary for directing a school string ensemble, such as arranging, bowing and basic string maintenance. Prerequisites: Music Education majors only or instructor permission
courses.prerequisites: Music education major or instructor permission. (Previous, Required)

courses.title: Middle School Music
courses.description: The study of developmentally appropriate materials, methods and skills for teaching music in the middle school. Topics include demonstrating on secondary instruments, the development of critical listening skills, creative activities, comprehensive musicianship, literature selection, research-based rehearsal strategies, scaffolding of instruction, assessment strategies, and reflection on teaching. Lesson planning and teaching are done in class and through practicum experiences. A field placement is required.
courses.prerequisites: Music education major or instructor permission. (Previous, Required)

courses.title: Arranging & Charting
courses.description: This course introduces students to the basic concepts used in arranging and charting for school music ensembles. Students will use computer sequencers and notational programs to create arrangements appropriate for public school instrumental and vocal ensembles. Students also will create and chart marching band shows for bands of various sizes, using dedicated computer charting programs.

courses.title: Seminar in Music Education
courses.description: An examination of the philosophical and psychological foundations of contemporary music education. Topics include aesthetic theories and their implications for music education, as well as a study of the application of learning and developmental theories of students (elementary, middle and secondary) to the teaching and learning of music.

courses.title: Nurs Health Prof
courses.description: Professional nursing role is explored with students interested in the profession. Topics covered include historical foundations of nursing, current trends influencing the profession, and strategies for student success. This course helps students expand their world view of nursing and health care. This is an elective course open to all students and not required for the major.

courses.title: Nurse Provider: Pharmacology
courses.description: Focus on principles of pharmacology and pharmacological aspects of the major categories of medications as used in nursing practice using a systems approach. Special attention is given to implications of therapeutic treatment for nursing practice, and critical thinking and communication for safe medication administration. Prerequisite: Admission to the nursing program. Corequisite: NURS 242, NURS 245, NURS 251, NURS 261.
courses.prerequisites: Admission to Nursing program.  NURS 242, NURS 245, NURS 251, NURS 261. (Concurrent, Required)

courses.title: Nurse Provider:Pathophys
courses.description: Focus on pathophysiology of disease processes using a systems approach with an emphasis on nursing implications. Examine disease processes throughout the lifespan and across the health continuum.
courses.prerequisites: Admission to Nursing program. (Previous, Required) NURS 241, NURS 245, NURS 251, NURS 261 (Concurrent, Required)

courses.title: Nurse Provider Clinical I
courses.description: Use knowledge from general education, core courses, nursing concepts and theories to provide direct and indirect care to adults in community and long term care settings. Begin to enact the professional nurse role to provide leadership, patient advocacy, and education to adults. Prerequisite: Admission to the nursing program. Corequisites: NURS 241, NURS 242, NURS 251, NURS 261.
courses.prerequisites: Admission to Nursing program.  (Previous, Required) NURS 241, NURS 242, NURS 251, NURS 261 (Concurrent, Required)

courses.title: Care Des I: Health Assessment
courses.description: Focus on health assessment using a systems approach with an emphasis on nursing implications. Examine assessment of diverse individuals throughout the lifespan and the continuum of care. Prerequisite: Admission to the nursing program. Corequisites: NURS 241, NURS 242, NURS 245, NURS 261.
courses.prerequisites: Admission to Nursing program.  (Previous, Required) NURS 241, NURS 242, NURS 245, NURS 261 (Concurrent, Required)

courses.title: Professional Integration I
courses.description: Use knowledge from provider of care, clinical, and designer courses to begin formation of a professional identity. Simulation technology will be utilized to integrate knowledge from these courses. Prerequisite: Admission to the nursing program; Corequisite: NURS 241, NURS 242, NURS 245, NURS 251.
courses.prerequisites: Admission to Nursing program.  (Previous, Required) NURS 241, NURS 242, NURS 245, NURS 251 (Concurrent, Required)

courses.title: Evidence for Prof Nursing Prac
courses.description: Focus on identifying best evidence for professional nursing practice in all settings. Emphasis is on research, EBP, care management, and professional nurse identity. Concepts include professional identity, CT/reasoning, quality, care management, safety, and patient centered care.
courses.prerequisites: Admission to the Nursing Program (previous). MATH 132A, MATH 132B, PS 225!, PSYC 299, or SOC 225 (Previous or concurrent, Required)

courses.title: Intro to Baccalaureate Nursing
courses.description: Explore Baccalaureate education. Introduce nursing concepts related to the role of the baccalaureate nurse. This course is specifically created for the ADN to BSN Concurrent student.
courses.prerequisites: Admission to the ADN to BSN program (Previous, Required)

courses.title: Exploration of Nursing History
courses.description: Exploratory process focusing on historical trends, issues and advances influencing the profession of nursing with emphasis on specific events in the United States.

courses.title: Nurse Provider Concepts II
courses.description: Examine basic health concepts from a nursing perspective with an emphasis on chronic health conditions. Focus on the human experience across the lifespan and health continuum; concepts include comfort, mobility, elimination, end of life, and physchosocial integrity.
courses.prerequisites: NURS 241, NURS 242, NURS 245, NURS 251, NURS 261 (Previous, Required) NURS 345, NURS 351, NURS 361 (Concurrent, Required)

courses.title: Nurse Provider Clinical II
courses.description: Use knowledge from general education, core courses, nursing concepts and theories to provide direct and indirect care to adult individuals experiencing chronic health conditions. Enact the professional nurse role to provide leadership, patient advocacy, and education to adults.
courses.prerequisites: NURS 241, NURS 242, NURS 245, NURS 251, NURS 261 (Previous, Required) NURS 341, NURS 351, NURS 361 (Concurrent, Required)

courses.title: Nursing Care Designer II
courses.description: Develop knowledge and ability to provide, coordinate and manage care as part of the health care team with an emphasis on concepts such as communication, critical thinking, collaboration, conflict resolution, and advocacy. Focus on development of the professional nurse identity.
courses.prerequisites: NURS 241, NURS 242, NURS 245, NURS 251, NURS 261 (Previous, Required) NURS 341, NURS 345, NURS 361 (Concurrent, Required)

courses.title: Professional Integration II
courses.description: Use knowledge from provider of care, clinical, and designer courses to continue formulation of a professional identity. Simulation technology will be utilized to integrate knowledge from these courses.
courses.prerequisites: NURS 241, NURS 242, NURS 245, NURS 251, NURS 261 (Previous, Required) NURS 341, NURS 345, NURS 351 (Concurrent, Required)

courses.title: Nurse Provider Concepts III
courses.description: Examination of health concepts from a community and family nursing perspective. Focus on the human experience across the lifespan and health continuum; concepts include health promotion, reproduction, vulnerability, diversity, disaster, violence, and growth and development.
courses.prerequisites: NURS 341, NURS 345, NURS 351, NURS 361 (Previous, Required) NURS 375, NURS 381, NURS 391 (Concurrent, Required)

courses.title: Nurse Provider Clinical III
courses.description: Use knowledge from general education, core courses, nursing concepts and theories to provide direct and indirect patient centered care to individuals across the lifespan experiencing different levels of health in community settings. Enact the professional nurse role to provide leadership, patient advocacy, and education for vulnerable populations.
courses.prerequisites: NURS 341, NURS 345, NURS 351, NURS 361 (Previous, Required) NURS 371, NURS 381, NURS 391 (Concurrent, Required)

courses.title: Nursing Care of Populations
courses.description: Focus on community, family, and public health, as well as epidemiology. A community assessment project will be completed, as well as use of simulated public and home health clinical practice. Social, political, and economic issues regarding the health of populations will be explored. Concepts will include clinical reasoning, advocacy, teaching/learning, health surveillance, violence, and disaster. Professional writing and use of evidence will be emphasized.

courses.title: Health Prom for Diverse Pop
courses.description: Focus on health promotion, disease prevention, and addressing the health care needs of diverse populations across the lifespan. Concepts include technology/information, health literacy, vulnerability/disparities, and structure/culture. Professional writing and evidence based practice will be emphasized.

courses.title: Nursing Care Designer III
courses.description: Develop knowledge and ability to provide, coordinate and manage care as part of the health care team with an emphasis on concepts such as research, evidence-based practice, care management and legal issues. Focus on development of a professional nurse identity.
courses.prerequisites: NURS 341, NURS 345, NURS 351, NURS 361 (Previous, Required) NURS 371, NURS 375, NURS 391 (Concurrent, Required)

courses.title: Human Trafficking
courses.description: A departmental course in a subject area not currently listed in the catalog. A descriptive title will appear on the Course Schedule and the transcript. Prerequisite: As listed in the Course Schedule.

courses.title: Professional Integration III
courses.description: Use knowledge from provider of care, clinical, and designer courses to continue formulation of a professional identity. Simulation technology will be utilized to integrate knowledge from these courses.
courses.prerequisites: NURS 341, NURS 345, NURS 351, NURS 361 (Previous, Required) NURS 371, NURS 375, NURS 381 (Concurrent, Required)

courses.title: Prof Integration I: RN/Concur
courses.description: Use knowledge from clinical experience and designer course to continue formulation of a professional identity. Simulation technology will be utilized to integrate knowledge.

courses.title: Prof Integration II for RNs
courses.description: Use knowledge from provider of care, clinical, and designer, coordinator, and manager courses to enact a professional identity. Simulation technology will be utilized to integrate knowledge from other courses.
courses.prerequisites: NURS 401, NURS 411. (Previous, Required) NURS 431 and Michigan RN license. (Previous, Required) NURS 431 and NURS 479 (Concurrent, Required) NURS 479 (Concurrent, Required)

courses.title: Nsg Care Designer III:RN/Conc
courses.description: Integrate leadership and management knowledge, skills, and attitudes as they relate to nurse led practice change at the microsystem level and influence organizational policy change. Emphasis will be on the concepts of empowerment, mentoring, change agent, health care economics, the political process, and the legal system.
courses.prerequisites: NURS 401, NURS 411. (Previous, Required) NURS 401  (Previous, Required) NURS 479, NURS 421 (Concurrent, Required)

courses.title: Nurse Provider Concepts IV
courses.description: Examine physiological health concepts from a nursing perspective with an emphasis on acute health conditions. Focus on human experiences across the lifespan and health continuum; concepts include thermoregulation, oxygenation, fluid & electrolyte, and physiological integrity in individuals and emerging families.
courses.prerequisites: NURS 371, NURS 375, NURS 381, NURS 391 (Previous, Required) NURS 445, NURS 451, NURS 461 (Concurrent, Required)

courses.title: Nurse Provider Clinical IV
courses.description: Use knowledge from general education, core courses, nursing concepts and theories to provide direct and indirect patient centered care across the lifespan (adults, women during childbirth, and children) experiencing acute health conditions. Enact the professional nurse role to provide bedside leadership for individuals including advocacy and education.
courses.prerequisites: NURS 371, NURS 375, NURS 381, NURS 391 (Previous, Required) NURS 441, NURS 451, NURS 461 (Concurrent, Required)

courses.title: Nursing Care Designer IV
courses.description: Examine leadership issues as they relate to the nursing profession, healthcare systems, and society. Emphasis is on concepts such as leadership and management, complexity, power, quality, interprofessional collaboration for change, finance, and organizational policy at the microsystem level.
courses.prerequisites: NURS 371, NURS 375, NURS 381, NURS 391 (Previous, Required) NURS 441, NURS 445, NURS 461 (Previous or concurrent, Required)

courses.title: Professional Integration IV
courses.description: Use knowledge from provider of care, clinical, and designer, coordinator, and manager courses to continue formulation of a professional identity. Simulation technology will be utilized to integrate knowledge from these courses.
courses.prerequisites: NURS 371, NURS 375, NURS 381, NURS 391 (Previous, Required) NURS 441, NURS 445, NURS 451 (Concurrent, Required)

courses.title: Nurs Provider Concepts V
courses.description: Examine complex physiological health concepts from a nursing perspective with an emphasis on complex acute health conditions. Focus on complex human experiences across the lifespan and health continuum; concepts include thermoregulation, oxygenation, fluid & electrolyte, and physiological integrity in individuals. Prerequisites: NURS 441, NURS 445, NURS 451, NURS 455, NURS 461. Corequisites: NURS 475, NURS 481, NURS 491
courses.prerequisites: NURS 441, NURS 445, NURS 451, NURS 455, NURS 461 (Previous, Required) NURS 475, NURS 481, NURS 494 (Concurrent, Required)

courses.title: Nurse Provider Clinical V
courses.description: Synthesis of knowledge from general education, core courses, nursing concepts and theories to provide direct and indirect patient centered care to diverse individuals and groups across the lifespan experiencing complex health issues in acute care settings. Immersion in the professional nurse role to provide leadership for health care teams, patient advocacy, and education. Prerequisite: NURS 441, NURS 445, NURS 451, NURS 455, NURS 461. Corequisite: NURS 471, NURS 481, NURS 491
courses.prerequisites: NURS 441, NURS 445,  NURS 451, NURS 455, NURS 461 (Previous, Required) NURS 471, NURS 481, NURS 494 (Concurrent, Required)

courses.title: Nursing and Health Care System
courses.description: Focus is on microsystem and macrosystems, and influencing organizational policy change. Concepts will include power, change, health care economics, transition, and regulatory issues. A QI/change project will be required at an approved agency/work setting. Professional writing and use of evidence will be emphasized.
courses.prerequisites: NURS-377, NURS-379, NURS-401, and current, unencumbered RN licensure in Michigan. (Previous, Required)

courses.title: Nursing Care Designer V
courses.description: Integrate leadership and management knowledge, skills, and attitudes as they relate to nurse led practice change at the microsystem level and influence organizational policy change. Emphasis will be on the concepts of empowerment, mentoring, change agent, health care economics, the political process, and the legal system. Prerequisites: NURS 441, NURS 445, NURS 451, NURS 455, NURS 461. Corequisites: NURS 471, NURS 475, NURS 491
courses.prerequisites: NURS 441, NURS 445, NURS 451, NURS 455, NURS 461 (Previous, Required) NURS 471, NURS 475, NURS 494 (Concurrent, Required)

courses.title: Issues in Neuroscience Nursing
courses.description: This course will discuss the history of neuroscience nursing. Topics covered will include the brain and spine, cranial nerves, stroke, brain tumors, and acute and chronic neurological diseases. Course will include instruction on stroke assessment using the National Institutes of Health Stroke, Scale (NIHSS). Nurse care and current research evidence on the treatment the above mentioned conditions will be included.

courses.title: Professional Integration V
courses.description: Use knowledge from provider of care, clinical, and designer courses to enact a professional identity. Simulation technology will be utilized to integrate knowledge from these courses. Prerequisites: NURS 441, NURS 445, NURS 451, NURS 455, NURS 461. Corequisites: NURS 471, NURS 475, NURS 481
courses.prerequisites: NURS 441, NURS 445, NURS 451, NURS 455, NURS 461 (Previous, Required) NURS 471, NURS 475, NURS 481 (Concurrent, Required)

courses.title: Patho for Fnp
courses.description: Advanced study for Family Nurse Practitioner (FNP) students of the pathophysiologic changes due to disease processes along with the compensatory mechanisms. Emphasized is the understanding of the clinical manifestations of disease processes so that physiologically sound clinical management can be developed. Includes the analysis of the mechanism(s) of production of the symptoms and signs of different disease syndromes.
courses.prerequisites: Admission to a Graduate Nursing program. (Previous or concurrent, Recommended)

courses.title: Genomics Comp. ANP
courses.description: Provides a scientific foundation of genetics and genomics from a health care perspective. Focuses on the role of genetics/genomics in improving our ability to predict disease susceptibility, provide individualized preventive screening and risk reduction interventions, and target disease treatment. Prepares graduate nursing students to assume clinical and leadership roles in translating these genetic/genomic advances into effective health care within an interprofessional context.
courses.prerequisites: Admission to a graduate nursing program with FNP concentration. (Previous, Required)

courses.title: Diagnostic Reasoning
courses.description: Develops and refines safe clinical decision-making strategies used by family nurse practitioners in interprofessional primary care settings. Emphasizes acquisition and analysis of relevant data to formulate differential diagnoses for common acute, chronic, and complex health conditions. Focuses on the judicious selection and accurate interpretation of screening and diagnostic tests as an integral component of the diagnostic reasoning process.
courses.prerequisites: Admission to graduate nursing program with FNP concentration. (Previous, Required)

courses.title: Theory & Knowledge Develop
courses.description: Examination of the development of knowledge and theoretical foundation of advanced nursing practice. Emphasis is on the use of concepts and theories as the basis for advanced nursing practice including a sense of professional heritage. Conceptualizes the nurse as clinical scholar and collaborative knowledge worker.
courses.prerequisites: Admission to a graduate NURS program. (Previous, Required)

courses.title: Nursing Leadership & Ethics
courses.description: Examination of organizational and ethical systems leadership as a professional nursing expectation in a variety of settings. Emphasis is on the relationship of nursing leadership to interprofessional collaboration for improving patient and population health outcomes is emphasized.
courses.prerequisites: Admission to a graduate NURS program. (Previous, Required)

courses.title: Pathophysiology & Pharmacology
courses.description: Advanced study of the knowledge of pathophysiology and pharmacology to support advanced clinical reasoning skills. Emphasis is on the development of knowledge to lead evidenced-based practice improvements in caring for complex patients in a variety of healthcare settings. Prerequisites: Admission to MSN program.
courses.prerequisites: Admission to the MSN program  (Previous, Required)

courses.title: Family Health Care II
courses.description: Advanced nursing practice management of adults with chronic multi-system complex illnesses in rural and underserved primary care settings within an interprofessional context. Emphasizes utilization of theory, critical thinking, evidence-based practice, and cultural context to formulate differential diagnoses, clinical impressions, diagnoses, and treatment and evaluation plans.
courses.prerequisites: NURS 671. Take NURS*674 (Previous or concurrent, Required)

courses.title: FNP Clinical
courses.description: Synthesize theory and research in advanced practice nursing for providing culturally sensitive quality patient-centered care for individuals and families across the lifespan. Emphasis is on the provision of evidence-based care within the context of rapidly expanding knowledge and the changing healthcare environment. Focuses on the uniqueness of the rural community. Each 1 credit equals 60 practice experience hours toward the total of 600 practice experience hours. Students take 2-4 credits (120-240 practice experience hours) concurrent with three FNP didactic courses.
courses.prerequisites: NURS 670 (Previous, Required) NURS 671, NURS 672, NURS 673 (Concurrent, Required)

courses.title: Research Project I
courses.description: Application of research techniques to study a nursing phenomenon. This hybrid course is designed to support students during the initial research project process in collaboration with the research chairperson.

courses.title: Adv Peds Ass, Patho, & Pharm
courses.description: An examination of special topics in the area of nursing.

courses.title: FNP Rural Res. I
courses.description: Introduces the student to the rural context of advanced nursing practice. Explores the historical, geographic, demographic, cultural, socio-economic and technological factors and their influence on the provision of primary health care in rural and remote populations. Synthesis of theoretical and diagnostic knowledge is facilitated through rurally-focused technology-centric virtual simulation activities.

courses.title: Psych Mh Care Adults
courses.description: Integrates assessment, diagnosis and treatment of acute and chronic mental health disorders of adult and geriatric clients. Differential diagnoses and treatment plans include the influence of genetic, age, gender, and cultural variables, psychosocial needs, laboratory findings and diagnostic studies. Group skills, community resources, advocacy, and preventive mental health measures are emphasized.

courses.title: Pmhnp Clinical
courses.description: Direct practice experiences with individuals, families and groups provides opportunities for application of assessment, diagnosis and psychotherapeutic skills in managing acute and chronic mental health conditions across the lifespan and in a variety of clinical settings. Emphasis is on the provision of evidence-based care with a focus on the use of telehealth and emerging technologies to improve access to quality mental health care. Course may be taken only 3 times for credit (9 credits total in program with 540 clinical hours total).
courses.prerequisites: NURS 710, NURS 712, NURS 716 (Previous, Required) NURS 731, NURS 733, or NURS 735 (Concurrent, Required)

courses.title: Health Assessment & Genomics
courses.description: Advanced knowledge of history and physical, developmental, functional and psychosocial assessment techniques across the lifespan. Emphasis is on systems of culturally responsive health and physical assessment utilizing genetic and genomic applications. Addresses health promotion strategies incorporating genetic, environmental, and genomic factors.
courses.prerequisites: Admission to a graduate nursing program. (Previous or concurrent, Recommended)

courses.title: Scholarship of Adv Nurs Pra
courses.description: Examination of reflective practice and inquiry for the doctorally prepared nurse. Emphasis is on interdisciplinary perspectives of the scholarship of practice as it relates to the domain of knowledge for advanced nursing practice.
courses.prerequisites: Admission to the DNP program (Previous, Required)

courses.title: Knowledge Dev for ANP
courses.description: Application of theoretical and philosophical perspectives to advanced nursing practice. Emphasis is on the exploration of the knowledge base for advanced nursing practice.
courses.prerequisites: Admission to the DNP program (Previous, Required)

courses.title: Transcultural Nursing
courses.description: Introduction to transcultural nursing theory which will assist students in understanding their own and different cultures, values, belief systems and practices. Emphasis will be placed on learning about cultures frequently encountered in mid-Michigan as related to the provision of health care.

courses.title: Nursing Leadership and Ethics
courses.description: Examine leadership, management, complexity, and interprofessional collaboration. Concepts include the legal system, ethical guidelines, conflict resolution, care coordination, informatics, interprofessional collaboration, and the political environment. Professional writing and use of evidence will be emphasized.

courses.title: Nursing in the Netherlands
courses.description: A departmental course in a subject area not currently listed in the catalog. A descriptive title will appear on the Course Schedule and the transcript.

courses.title: Pain Mgmt Across the Lifespan
courses.description: Pain management of acute and chronic pain. Topics covered are pathophysiology, pharmacological, complimentary and interventional, treatments. Assessing pain in verbally impaired individual, cancer pain, end of life care, physical dependency, addiction and abuse will also be covered.

courses.title: Pharm for FNP
courses.description: Study of pharmacology for family nurse practitioner (FNP) students eligible for prescriptive authority. Emphasis is on appropriate pharmacologic therapeutics for the prevention and treatment of prevalent acute and chronic diseases. Addresses pharmacogenetics, legal/ethical and prescribing implications, patient education, and monitoring for drug interactions, drug overuse/abuse and adherence to therapy.

courses.title: Healthcare Policy & Funding
courses.description: Overview of healthcare policy, funding, and regulations for advanced nursing practice in a variety of settings including legislative, academic, clinical practice, and community. Emphasis is on nursing's relationships within and among organizations and how nurses influence and become engaged in policy.
courses.prerequisites: Admission to graduate nursing program (Previous, Required)

courses.title: Research in Adv Nurs Practice
courses.description: Study of research design and data analysis appropriate to the investigation of nursing phenomena. Emphasis is on the use of evidence-based practice to enhance outcomes.
courses.prerequisites: NURS 638, and MATH 132A, MATH 132B, PSYC 299 or PS 225. (Previous, Required)

courses.title: Family Health Care I
courses.description: Analysis of concepts such as protection, maturation, nourishment, and procreation within the frameworks of family and community across the lifespan for family nurse practitioner students. Emphasis is on culturally competent advanced assessment, evaluation, and family nurse practitioner management of women's health including sexual and reproductive health and the care of children from the neonate to the adolescent.
courses.prerequisites: NURS 610, NURS 612, and NURS 670. Take NURS*674 (Previous or concurrent, Required)

courses.title: Research Project II
courses.description: Application of research techniques to study a nursing phenomenon. This hybrid course is designed to support students during the intermediate research project process in collaboration with the research chairperson.

courses.title: FNP Rural Residency II
courses.description: Explores the impact and etiology of chronic multi-system complex illnesses in rural populations, identifies barriers to health care delivery and access, and examines how technology can overcome the unique cultural, geographic, and sociocultural barriers that typify rural health care. Synthesis of theoretical and diagnostic knowledge is facilitated through rurally-focused technology-centric simulation activities.

courses.title: Psychother Found
courses.description: Evidenced based psychotherapeutic approaches are explored for the treatment of individuals, families and groups to provide the foundation for clinical management of chronic and acute mental health conditions across the lifespan. Applications of Cognitive Behavioral Therapy and Motivational Interviewing are examined in detail.
courses.prerequisites: Admission to PMHNP Post-Graduate Certificate. (Previous, Required)

courses.title: Psych Mh Care Child
courses.description: Integrates assessment, diagnosis and treatment of children and adolescents with behavioral, developmental, and mental health disorders or at risk for mental illness within the context of their families and communities. Differential diagnoses and treatment plans include the influence of genetic, age, gender, and cultural variables, developmental stage, laboratory findings and diagnostic studies. Strategies and interventions in education, family support, and facilitated family and group communication specific to mental health are emphasized.

courses.title: Epidemiology/Pop Hlth in ANP
courses.description: Identification, analysis, and evaluation of key population health concepts utilized in advanced nursing practice. Emphasis is on broad ecological, global and social determinants of health and evidence-based clinical prevention strategies and interventions. Introduces students to epidemiologic and community health concepts and methods.
courses.prerequisites: Admission to a graduate NURS program. (Previous, Required)

courses.title: Translational Scholarship
courses.description: Examination of the meaning and application of clinical scholarship as foundational to advanced nursing practice. Emphasis is on the integration of theories from nursing and other disciplines to frame interprofessional clinical scholarship and the ability to translate research into practice. Includes the scholarship of application as a competency for experts in specialized advanced nursing practice.

courses.title: DNP Practice
courses.description: Practice experience designed to enable student to achieve learning objectives related to DNP competencies. Required credits based on transcript review to achieve a minimum of 1000 practice hours.

courses.title: Foundations in OT
courses.description: Occupational therapy is introduced within the context of the Conceptual Framework of Therapeutic Occupation. Occupation from a historical perspective, the client-therapist rapport process, and clinical ethics will be addressed. This course is required for all undergraduate occupational therapy courses or permission of instructor.

courses.title: Therapeutic Occupation
courses.description: The course focus is on occupational synthesis used to design occupational forms that are meaningful and purposeful to elicit occupational performance, adaptation, and compensation. Occupational analysis purposes and processes will be explored as a means to design and select individualized therapeutic occupations.

courses.title: Dev Structure Neurologic Cond
courses.description: Neurological and neuro-muscular systems are studied with selected conditions including etiology, symptoms, and occupational performance deficits resulting from disease or injury. Prerequisite: OT 302 or permission of instructor.

courses.title: Development Struct Ortho Cond
courses.description: The impact of various diseases and injuries on body structures and functions are studied. Selected orthopedic and musculo-skeletal conditions including the etiology, symptoms, and occupational performance deficits resulting from disease or injury will be addressed. Prerequisite: OT 302 or permission of instructor.

courses.title: Occupational Assess Neuro
courses.description: The occupational therapy role in the assessment of occupational performance strengths and deficits in the presence of neurological, and degenerative disorders and trauma is presented. Must be taken concurrently with OT 515.

courses.title: Occ Adaptation Neurologic Cond
courses.description: Occupational therapy management of, in collaboration with, clients experiencing neurologic dysfunction is explored. Contemporary theories and concepts, including rehabilitation, neuro-rehabilitation, and neuro-occupation approaches and foundations will be presented with emphasis on remediation and adapting to occupational performance limitations.

courses.title: Occ Assessment Across Lifespan
courses.description: The assessment of occupational performance strength and deficits throughout the lifespan is introduced. Formal and informal assessment methods will be presented. Age and stage specific factors affecting the assessment process will be identified.

courses.title: Occ Adaptation Across Lifespan
courses.description: The occupational therapy role in facilitating occupational performance and adaptation to disabling conditions throughout the lifespan is presented. Emphasis will be placed on the pediatric and geriatric populations. Pre-clinical experiences will be included throughout the course requiring multiple visits to community settings.

courses.title: Occ Assess Psychosocial Cond
courses.description: Occupational therapy assessment of psychiatric, developmental, and psychosocial conditions are presented. Emphasis is on the role of the occupational therapist in the use of formal and informal assessment measures of occupational performance strengths and deficits with these populations.

courses.title: Occ Adaptation Psychosocial
courses.description: Occupational therapy interventions for psychiatric, developmental, and psychosocial disabilities are presented. Emphasis is on the role of the occupational therapist in the collaborative treatment of occupational performance deficits with these populations. Contemporary theoretical approaches will be identified with a particular focus on community based intervention methods.

courses.title: Lvl 1 Fieldwork Psychosocial
courses.description: Level 1 Fieldwork will allow the student to experience the varied occupational therapy roles and opportunities for intervention within clinical and community settings for clients experiencing psychiatric, developmental, and psychosocial conditions. Seminar emphasis will be placed on identifying clinical-based research opportunities.
courses.prerequisites: OT 540, OT 545 or instructor permission. (Concurrent, Required)

courses.title: Critical Inquiry II
courses.description: This course is a continuation of OT 500. Provided IRB approval, the research proposals developed in OT 500 will be implemented in this course. Emphasis is placed on the first hand experience of the research process (e.g., recruitment of participants, data collection and data analysis, manuscript writing, etc.). A scholarly written research manuscript is required at the end of the course. Prerequisite: OT 550.

courses.title: Lvl II Fieldwork Physical
courses.description: Students engage in a 12-week full-time internship emphasizing treatment of individuals experiencing physical and/or orthopedic disabilities. Students will assume management and treatment responsibilities for an assigned caseload of clients of varying ages and diagnoses under the supervision of an occupational therapist. Prerequisite: Completion of all OT coursework except OT 675 or permission of the department.

courses.title: Lvl II Fieldwork Psychosocial
courses.description: Students engage in a 12-week full-time internship emphasizing community based service models. Under the supervision of an occupational therapist, the student will assume responsibilities in the assessment and management of clients. Research and/or the administration of occupational therapy services may also be expected. Prerequisite: completion of all OT coursework except OT 670 or permission of the department.

courses.title: Dev Structure Across Lifespan
courses.description: The impact of various acquired and congenital conditions on occupational performance along the developmental continuum, with particular emphasis on pediatric and geriatric populations, is examined. Prerequisite: OT 302 or permission of instructor.

courses.title: Dev Struct Psychosocial Cond
courses.description: The impact of the etiology, symptomology and functional sequelae of psychiatric, psychosocial and developmental psychopathology are studied. The psychopathology and the conditions' effect on occupational performance will be examined. Prerequisite: OT 302 or permission of instructor.

courses.title: Critical Inquiry I
courses.description: This course will address evidence-based practice concepts and methods and the implications for occupational therapy practice and research. Applied statistical tools, data collection, and data analysis techniques will be studied relative to quantitative and qualitative research. Appropriate computerized data analysis software programs will be introduced and applied. The student will develop a research proposal.

courses.title: Occ Assessment Orthopedic Cond
courses.description: The overall assessment and specific evaluative procedures related to orthopedic and musculoskeletal conditions of the upper extremity and axial skeleton are presented. Emphasis is on the role of occupational therapy in the assessment of occupational performance deficits secondary to trauma and work-related injuries. Functional capacity and work-site analysis are included.

courses.title: Occ Adaptation Orthopedic Cond
courses.description: Occupational therapy intervention and management of, in collaboration with clients, experiencing disability of the hand, upper extremity and axial skeleton is explored.

courses.title: Lvl 1 Fieldwork Physical Cond
courses.description: The seminar introduces fieldwork policies, procedures, and documentation methods and promotes concepts of professional behavior and communication. It also provides the opportunity to experience current professional roles, the occupational therapy process, and standards of practice.
courses.prerequisites: OT 520, OT 525 or instructor permission. (Concurrent, Required)

courses.title: Therapeutic Technologies
courses.description: The application of therapeutic technologies to promote occupational performance is explored with regard to cognitive augmentation, technology in the classroom and at work, technologies aiding manipulation and control of the environment, seating systems as enablers for therapeutic/assistive/adaptive technologies, technologies enabling mobility, transportation and safety, and sensory aids for visual and auditory impairments. The role of the occupational therapist will be explored in the application of augmentative and alternative communication systems and processes and the provision of home evaluation and modification.

courses.title: OT Leadership
courses.description: Contemporary management systems and models and leadership theories are presented within the context of occupational therapy practice. Students will also identify models of systems change appropriate for application to occupational therapy.

courses.title: Graduate Research Project
courses.description: Guidance is provided in the completion of the Capstone Research Project, as well as dissemination of research findings in appropriate venues.

courses.title: Professional Role Transitions
courses.description: Students will reflect on their occupational therapy education through development of a professional portfolio. Successful completion of a comprehensive examination is also mandated within this course. Level II fieldwork policies, procedures, and expectations will be presented. Prerequisite: successful completion of all OT curriculum coursework (exception of OT 670 and OT 675).

courses.title: Introduction to Logic
courses.description: An introduction to critical thinking and writing with an emphasis on improving students' skills in developing and evaluating logical arguments. Topics include basic logical relationships, use of evidence and sources, precise definition, informal fallacies, analogical arguments, and writing persuasive and critical papers.

courses.title: Appl Ethics-Engr & Comp Tech
courses.description: An introduction to moral theory with special attention to: (a)social policies concerning life and death issues, or (b)issues in engineering and computer technologies.

courses.title: East Asian Civilizations
courses.description: An introduction to the history, arts, culture and philosophical and religious ideas of China, Japan and the east Asian region, including Confucianism, Taoism, Shinto, Buddhism and related traditions; also east Asian music, film, literature and customs.

courses.title: Philosophical Themes in Lit
courses.description: Selected readings from important works of world literature in which philosophical issues are treated. May include works of Sophocles, Aeschylus, Dante, Dostoyevsky, Camus, Sartre, Borges, and others; focus will vary.

courses.title: History of Philosophy: Modern
courses.description: A survey of Western philosophy from the seventeenth century to the twentieth, emphasizing the contributions of Descartes, Spinoza, Leibniz, Locke, Berkeley, Hume, Kant, Hegel, and Nietsche. Epistemology, social and political philosophy, and ethics are stressed. PHIL 123 recommended but not required.

courses.title: Philosophy of Religion
courses.description: Major issues in the philosophy of religion include monotheism vs. polytheism, the attributes of God, arguments for belief in God, grounds for disbelief in God, direct experience of the Divine, the reliability of scriptural sources, faith without proof, problems of religious language, verifiability, religion as attitude, alternatives to anthropomorphism in religion, theist vs. non-theist religious belief and immorality. Readings will be included from scriptural and philosophical sources.

courses.title: Intro to Western Philosophy
courses.description: An interdisciplinary introduction to Western history, arts, culture and ideas emphasizing philosophical contributions. The major philosophical traditions and problems originating between the Presocratic period and the 17th century will be emphasized.

courses.title: Prof Ethics: Legal System
courses.description: An introduction to moral theory, with special attention to moral issues that arise in the practices of criminal justice and professions related to the United States legal system. these may include issues relevant to policy-making, the role of police, corruption and "the noble cause", loyalty and whistleblowing, legal ethics, preventative detention, and corrections.

courses.title: Applied Ethics in Society
courses.description: An introduction to moral theory and the application of ethics to contemporary social policy and social issues. The course may explore ethical problems that arise in society such as inequality, warfare, freedom, emerging technologies, civil disobedience, or treatment of animals.

courses.title: South Asian Civilizations
courses.description: An introduction to the history, arts, culture and philosophical and religious ideas of India, Pakistan and the south Asian region, including Hinduism, Buddhism, Islam and related traditions such as Jainism and Sikhism; also south Asian music, film, literature and customs.

courses.title: Philosophy of Law
courses.description: An examination of conceptual problems in the law and legal systems, especially those pertaining to the relationship between the law and morality and to issues of responsibility. Special emphasis will be reserved for considering the nature of law, legal interpretation, and the relationship between punishment and responsibility. PHIL 123 is recommended but not required.

courses.title: Science & Religion/Phil Issues
courses.description: Critical discussion of questions in contemporary philosophy of science: What is the relation between theory and observation? What distinguishes science from non-science? Are unobservable entities (e.g., quarks) real or merely devices for making predictions? What is the relation between physics and the other natural sciences?

courses.title: Earth Space Science A: Geology
courses.description: A study of the structure and composition of the Earth, the rocks that form its crust and the geological processes that have shaped and are shaping its surface such as water, wind and ice. Laboratory study of common rocks, minerals and fossils is included. A laboratory is included. Possible field trips. (3-2)

courses.title: Earth Space Sci B: Meteorology
courses.description: An examination of the wonders and science of the atmosphere that surrounds us. Topics include: description and causes of the local weather and climate, how weather forecasts are made, thunderstorms, tornadoes, hurricanes, blizzards and other violent weather, climate change and the effect of weather on human activities. (4-0)

courses.title: Earth Sp Sci C: Astronomy
courses.description: A descriptive study of the methods and principles of modern astronomy. Topics include: planets, moons, asteroids, comets, meteors, sun, stars, nebulae, galaxies, cosmology and subjects of current interest such as quasars, pulsars and black holes. (4-0).

courses.title: Our Physical World
courses.description: A survey of the universe and the laws that govern it. This course will introduce the students to the scientific method, physical principles, and applications of these principles that are interesting and relevant to modern society. The course also may include historical, cultural, and environmental aspects of physics. The student must be comfortable with simple algebra skills. A laboratory is included. (3-2)

courses.title: General Physics I
courses.description: Introductory physics without using calculus. Concept of vectors, one and two dimensional motion of a particle. Newton's laws of motion, law of gravitation, conservation laws of linear momentum, angular momentum and energy, ideal gases, heat and thermodynamics are treated systematically with emphasis in practical applications. Recommended for majors in biology and health sciences. (4-0)

courses.title: General Physics I Lab
courses.description: Experiments related to topics covered in PHYS 111. (0-3)

courses.title: General Physics II
courses.description: Continuation of PHYS 111. Coulomb's Law, the concept of electrical fields, electric current and Ohm's Law, magnetic fields due to electric currents, the force on a current in a magnetic field. Some ideas in modern physics such as relativity and quantum theory are introduced. (4-0) Prerequisite: PHYS 111.

courses.title: General Physics II Lab
courses.description: Experiments related to topics covered in PHYS 112. (0-3)

courses.title: Physics for Health Sciences
courses.description: An introduction to basic physics concepts for students interested in occupations in health field. Topics will include mechanics, fluids, heat, sound, light, electricity, magnetism and nuclear physics. Students will use basic algebra in this course. Prerequisite: MATH 082 or satisfactory score on placement test.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 082 or satisfactory score on math placement test. (Previous, Required)

courses.title: Analytical Physics I
courses.description: Introductory college physics using calculus, mechanics, wave motion, thermodynamics and kinetic theory of gases. Recommended for majors in physics, chemistry, mathematics, engineering and technology. (4-0)

courses.title: Introductory Physics I Lab
courses.description: Experiments related to topics covered in PHYS 211. (0-3) Corequisite: PHYS 211.

courses.title: Analytical Physics II
courses.description: Continuation of PHYS 211. Electricity and magnetism, optics and modern physics. (4-0) Prerequisite: PHYS 211.

courses.title: Introductory Physics II Lab
courses.description: Experiments related to topics covered in PHYS 212. (0-3) Corequisite: PHYS 212.

courses.title: Intro to Modern Physics
courses.description: Relativity, particle and wave properties, atomic structure, quantum mechanics, atomic nucleus and nuclear transformation. (4-0) Prerequisite: PHYS 112.
courses.prerequisites: PHYS 112 or PHYS 212, and MATH 162. (Previous, Required)

courses.title: Mathematical Methods
courses.description: Topics selected from vector analysis, Fourier series, special functions & partial differential equations, complex variables, Laplace transforms and Fourier transforms, with emphasis on physical and engineering applications. (3-0)

courses.title: Modern Optics & Holography
courses.description: Diffraction and interference, Fourier optical transformations, optical information processing, holography, rainbow holography and applications, holographic interferometry, fiber optics. (2-3) Prerequisite: PHYS 112 or PHYS 212.
courses.prerequisites: PHYS 112 or PHYS 212, and MATH 161 (Previous, Required)

courses.title: Electricity & Magnetism
courses.description: DC and AC circuits, Maxwell's equations, electrostatics, magnetostatics and introduction to electrodynamics. (4-0)

courses.title: Junior Laboratory
courses.description: Experiments designed to illustrate basic principles of physics and the application of current physics laboratory techniques. (1-3)

courses.title: Physical Optics
courses.description: Optical image formation, diffraction and interference of light, light polarization; optical transformations, interaction of light with matter.

courses.title: Rule of Law
courses.description: Focusing on a single, accessible political science topic (e.g., the politics of Afghanistan, environmental policy), students will develop their proficiency in writing effective research texts. No prior knowledge of political science is required or expected. Prerequisite: ENGL 111.

courses.title: Intro to Political Science
courses.description: A general introduction to basic concepts and methods of study. Required of those wishing to major in political science.

courses.title: The American Political System
courses.description: Survey of the development of the American political system. Emphasis upon political process. Includes review of executive, legislative, judicial and local governmental processes, as well as public opinion, interest groups, communications and political parties.

courses.title: World Politics
courses.description: An introductory, communication-intensive exploration of the nature and structure of world politics with emphasis upon the nature and sources of international and transnational political behavior. Selected contemporary issues will be examined.

courses.title: Statistics
courses.description: Introductory, communication-intensive, statistical methodology course. Methods covered include descriptive statistics, Chi square, t-tests, anova correlations and regression. The course is intended to enhance the ability to understand and manipulate numerical data, and the ability to respond to arguments and positions based on numbers and statistics.

courses.title: Gender and Politics
courses.description: Examines contemporary American women's and men's relationship to politics by analyzing their connections to the state, their status as citizens, and their political interests and activism. The course focuses on a range of topics including gender differences in political behavior, specific public policies for which women have worked, and the impact and interests of men and women from the Religious Right.

courses.title: Moot Court
courses.description: This class consists of the application of a substantive hypothetical case problem each year. Students will read and brief actual cases, and prepare oral and written arguments for a yearly competition. The class teaches essential skills for prelaw and criminal justice students, including critical thinking, analytical writing, and rhetorical skills. The class includes substantive written assignments, collaborative learning, graded evaluation, and requisite attendance.

courses.title: Am. Const. Law: Rights & Liber
courses.description: The history and development of the United States' constitutional law. Emphasis upon the development of basic principles and doctrines established by the United States Supreme Court as they pertain to Civil Rights and Civil Liberties. Includes in-depth analysis of selected Supreme Court decisions.

courses.title: Public Policy Making in U.S.
courses.description: An in-depth review of the public policy making process within the American political system.

courses.title: Advanced Moot Court
courses.description: Allows advanced students to further their knowledge and understanding of the United States Supreme Court and the creation and argument of a case in front of a simulated Supreme Court.

courses.title: Model United Nations
courses.description: Students in this course will develop an experiential-based understanding of the United Nations and international diplomacy. As students prepare for their roles at the American Model United Nations Conference, they will study current events, the structure and operation of the UN, and diplomatic procedures. Research, papers, and presentations will focus on topics related to the nations(s) that SVSU will represent at the conference. Concurrent requirement: Registration for the American Model United Nations.
courses.prerequisites: Registration for the American Model United Nations. Contact instructor for details. (Concurrent, Required)

courses.title: Advanced Model UN
courses.description: Allows advanced students to further develop their knowledge and understanding of the protocol and procedures of diplomacy and participate in the United Nations simulations. Credits: 1 (may be taken up to three times)

courses.title: Classical Political Thought
courses.description: The study of political order, justice, and human nature in classical and Christian civilizations. The works of thinkers such as Plato, Aristotle, Cicero, Augustine, Aquinas, Luther, Calvin, Mainmoindes, Al-Farabi, and Spinoza will be studied in order to understand what constitutes the good political life and its role in human flourishing.

courses.title: Evaluation Research
courses.description: This capstone course is designed as an exploration of policy analysis and program evaluation methods with particular attention to the role of public administration. Topics include measurement, research design, working with stakeholders, techniques and best practices for incorporating, evaluation with planning, implementation, budgeting and human resource management.

courses.title: International Law
courses.description: This course provides a survey of general parameters of international law as well as some of the current issues such as piracy, war crimes, genocides, human rights, and environmental law. The class utilizes a variety of means to gain a better understanding of international law, including a moot court or mock trial exercise and case briefing of major international legal cases.

courses.title: Equal Protection & Race
courses.description: This course will focus on equal protection as it pertains to racial discrimination. Relevant U.S. Supreme Court decisions throughout the nation's history will be examined in their legal, social and political contexts.

courses.title: Animals, Habitats, & Politics
courses.description: A study of the environmental and animal rights movements, tracing their historical development and shifting policy goals, with particular emphasis on legislation enacted in the twentieth century.

courses.title: Public Budgeting and Finance
courses.description: An examination of the theory and practice of public budgeting and the basics of public finance, the budget process, budget formats, the budget cycle, capital budgets, revenue sources including taxation, intergovernmental fiscal relations, debt management, and cash management in public organizations.

courses.title: Political Economy
courses.description: This course examines the institutional structures, political processes, and impact of international organizations on international and domestic politics. This course will focus on the topic of international development, as well as examine major theories of capitalism and its critics and the international organizations that comprise the international economic system. The international organizations and states involved in the current economic system are the primary focus of this course.

courses.title: Modern Political Thought
courses.description: The study of political order, property, and the state in modern western civilization. The works of such thinkers as Machiavelli, Hobbes, Locke, Mill, Smith, Montesquieu, Rousseau, Kant, Hegel, Marx, Nietzsche, Heidegger, Weber, Strauss, and Voegelin will be studied in order to understand the advantages and vulnerabilities that the modern political project offers to the questions of order, virtue, and the good life.

courses.title: Senior Seminar
courses.description: A capstone course required of all political science majors. The course will examine one political issue from the perspective of each of the major's content areas; theory, institutions, policy, and international.
courses.prerequisites: 30 credits of PS courses, including at least 3 each from the international and theory categories, and 6 each from the  institutions and policy categories. (Previous, Required)

courses.title: General Psychology
courses.description: Introduction to principles and methods utilized in the scientific study of human behavior. Emphasis will be on surveying the principles of sensation and perception, learning, motivation, emotion, intelligence, psychological testing, abnormal behavior, social psychology and the physiological bases of behavior. The format of this course is variable. Some sections will have a large lecture-small recitations format. Other sections will be single section classes.

courses.title: Scientific Found Psyc
courses.description: This class aims to provide a foundation of academic skills for those intending to major in psychology at SVSU, as well as those wishing to pursue careers involving applications of psychological science. The basic objective of this course is to help students acquire an appreciation of the scientific perspective as it is implemented in psychology.
